title: Type 2 Diabetes Management - Follow-up Consultation
content:
Patient presented for routine diabetes follow-up appointment. Patient has been managing Type 2 Diabetes for the past 3 years with oral medications and lifestyle modifications.

Current Medications:
- Metformin 1000mg twice daily
- Glimepiride 2mg once daily before breakfast
- Atorvastatin 20mg once daily at bedtime

Vital Signs:
- Blood Pressure: 128/82 mmHg
- Weight: 82 kg (down 3 kg from last visit)
- BMI: 28.5
- Temperature: 98.4Â°F

Laboratory Results (Fasting):
- Fasting Blood Glucose: 118 mg/dL (Target: <130 mg/dL)
- HbA1c: 6.8% (improved from 7.2% three months ago)
- Total Cholesterol: 185 mg/dL
- LDL: 102 mg/dL
- HDL: 48 mg/dL
- Triglycerides: 155 mg/dL
- Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL (normal kidney function)

Physical Examination:
- Alert and oriented
- No pedal edema
- Peripheral pulses intact bilaterally
- Foot examination: No ulcers, good sensation bilaterally
- Fundoscopic exam: No diabetic retinopathy noted
diagnosis:
Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - Well Controlled

Secondary Diagnoses:
- Dyslipidemia - Controlled on current medication
- Overweight (BMI 28.5) - Improving with lifestyle modifications

Patient shows excellent improvement in glycemic control with HbA1c reduction from 7.2% to 6.8%. Weight loss of 3 kg demonstrates good adherence to diet and exercise recommendations.
prescription:
Continue Current Medications:
1. Metformin 1000mg - Take 1 tablet twice daily with meals
2. Glimepiride 2mg - Take 1 tablet once daily before breakfast
3. Atorvastatin 20mg - Take 1 tablet once daily at bedtime

Refills: 90 days supply for all medications

No changes to current medication regimen as patient is responding well.
recommendations:
Diet and Lifestyle:
1. Continue low-carbohydrate, Mediterranean-style diet
2. Maintain current exercise routine of 30 minutes walking 5 days per week
3. Continue weight loss goal of 5-7% total body weight
4. Monitor blood glucose at home: Fasting glucose 3 times per week
5. Keep a food and exercise diary

Monitoring:
1. Schedule follow-up appointment in 3 months
2. Repeat HbA1c and lipid panel in 3 months
3. Annual eye examination with ophthalmologist (due in 2 months)
4. Annual foot examination - completed today
5. Continue home blood pressure monitoring

Patient Education:
1. Reviewed hypoglycemia symptoms and management
2. Discussed importance of medication compliance
3. Reinforced foot care guidelines
4. Provided dietary counseling materials
5. Encouraged continued adherence to treatment plan

Emergency Instructions:
Contact clinic immediately if:
- Blood glucose consistently >250 mg/dL or <70 mg/dL
- Signs of infection, especially foot wounds
- Chest pain, severe headache, or vision changes
- Unusual weakness, confusion, or excessive thirst
